poem:
**Afterlife Musings Over Coffee**

In the quiet kitchen,
where morning light bends on the table,
we sip our differing beliefs—
you in silence,
I with unwritten prayers.
Across oceans and borders, 
somewhere in Mexico, 
souls commune beyond reason,
their laughter threading through
the thin veil
of what we call here and gone.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "In My Time of Dying by Sebastian Junger review – from here to eternity For what it’s worth, the week before my mother died, I was talking with a Catalan friend about afterlife. There’s no such thing, she insisted, and I posited that her kind of rationalist atheism was largely invented by white people for white people and would make little sense to most of the poor world. We both have a stake in Mexico:". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
